qa.question: What do you mainly use your phone for?
qa.answer: I mostly use my phone to talk to my family and friends through calls and WhatsApp messages. Sometimes I listen to music and watch small videos. I don’t use many apps because I don’t understand them well.

qa.question: Do you share your phone with others?
qa.answer: Yes, I share my phone with my husband and children sometimes. They use it to call relatives or watch videos. It happens a few times a week, especially when they need to check something quickly.

qa.question: What are your favorite apps or features on your phone?
qa.answer: I like WhatsApp because it helps me talk to family far away. I also watch videos on YouTube. I don’t really think about what information these apps take; I just want to use them easily.

qa.question: When an app asks for permission, like to access your location, camera, or contacts, do you read and understand what it means?
qa.answer: No, I usually just press ‘Allow’ because the app won’t work without it. I don’t always read the messages or know what the permissions mean.

qa.question: How do you decide whether an app or website is safe to use?
qa.answer: I trust apps that my family or neighbors use. If someone I know says it’s good, I use it. Otherwise, I don’t open many new apps.

qa.question: Have you ever deleted a message, photo, or app because you didn’t want someone to see it?
qa.answer: Sometimes I delete messages if they are private or from someone I don’t want others to know about. But I don’t hide apps because I don’t know how.

qa.question: If your phone stops working and you need to give it for repair, what do you do before handing it over?
qa.answer: I usually just give the phone as it is. I feel worried that someone might see my photos or messages, but I don’t know how to remove them.

qa.question: Have you ever asked someone to help you with a phone problem?
qa.answer: Yes, I ask my son or the repair shop. I feel uncomfortable but I don’t have a choice. Sometimes I hope they don’t look at my private things.

qa.question: Who do you trust most when sharing personal or sensitive information?
qa.answer: I trust talking in person with my family most. On the phone or apps, I avoid sharing very private things.

qa.question: Have you used code words or nicknames to keep something private?
qa.answer: No, I don’t do that. I talk openly with people I trust.

qa.question: Have you ever helped someone install or use an app?
qa.answer: No, I don’t feel confident to help others. My son sometimes helps me.

qa.question: Do you know how to stop an app from using your camera, microphone, or location?
qa.answer: No, I don’t know how to do that.

qa.question: When you get a warning message (‘this app may harm your phone’), what do you usually do?
qa.answer: I usually ignore the warning because I don’t understand it. Sometimes I uninstall the app if it stops working.

qa.question: What do you think happens when you give an app access to your contacts or photos?
qa.answer: I think the app uses them to help me share pictures or talk to people. I don’t know if they keep or share the data elsewhere.

qa.question: Have you ever hesitated to take your phone for repair because of private content?
qa.answer: Yes, I worry about my photos and messages. But I don’t have many options.

qa.question: Has a repair person ever opened your gallery or apps without asking?
qa.answer: Yes, once the repair person looked at my photos. I felt uncomfortable but didn’t say anything because I was shy.

qa.question: Do you use a password or lock screen on your phone? Why or why not?
qa.answer: No, I don’t use a password because I find it hard to remember. Sometimes my husband uses my phone.

qa.question: Do you think apps from local developers are safer than international ones? Why?
qa.answer: I don’t really think about that. If the app is in my language, I feel more comfortable.

qa.question: Who do you turn to when you don’t understand a phone or app setting?
qa.answer: I ask my son or neighbors for help.

qa.question: Do people around you influence how you think about online safety?
qa.answer: Yes, they tell me to be careful and not to share passwords or click on strange links.

scenarios.Broken Phone: I give the phone to the repair shop as it is. I worry about privacy but don’t know what else to do.
scenarios.Sharing a Phone with Family: If my husband or children use the phone, I don’t hide messages or apps. I trust them.
scenarios.Installing a New App: I usually ask my son before installing new apps because I don’t understand the permissions.
scenarios.Helping an Elderly Relative: I would help my mother install an app but not explain much about permissions. I think it’s hard for her to understand.
scenarios.Using a Borrowed Phone: I try to avoid looking at anything private if I see it by accident.
scenarios.Selling or Giving Away a Phone: I don’t give away phones, so I haven’t thought about it much.
scenarios.Cloud Backup Surprise: I don’t know about cloud backup, so I would be surprised if photos still appear after deleting.
scenarios.Using Free Public WiFi: I don’t use public WiFi for important things like banking. I prefer using my own mobile data.
scenarios.Receiving a Lottery Call: I ignore such calls because I know they are usually scams.
scenarios.Sharing Account Details: I would not transfer money for others unless I trust them very much.
